reviewText:
Le sigh. Well, this game was funny-ish (how many electronic/software/computer puns can you fit into one scene?). Very charming, retro-chic style and music (the music is the best part). Makes me wish I was a high-roller sales exec in the 50s, when flying and traveling were still cool.

But other than the massive nostalgia blast, kind of not fun as a GAME. Lots of near-chuckle moments, almost no laughing. A single digit number of gross-out/creep-out moments. Jazzpunk really wants to be Maniac Mansion or Day or the Tentacle, or some other adventure game that really knows how to bring the funny, but those games it ain't. I got this as part of a bundle from another distributor that shall not be named. Glad I did, otherwise I'd have been annoyed at how short the game was. (A lot of my recorded game time was just pausing the game to go do something else). If you watch a playthrough, it's as fun as doing it yourself. So don't buy this game. Because you have better things to do. Like, anything.

I'm telling you, if you buy this game and finish it after reading this review, you'll be like, Man

reviewText:
This is an first person adventure that plays with any preconceptions the player has.

Your protagonist is a secret agent called Polyblank that gets sent on various proposterous missions, like extracting an artificial kidney from a cowboy.
The art style is everything here, and if you play this without exploring this weird and curious place, you can probably finish this game in under an hour. But that's not what its there for.
You will feel genuinely rewarded digging up an mammoth in an icecube at the beach or smuggling a carrier pigeon to the next mission.
This game is seriously funny without being insulting to your intelligence and I totally fell in love with its quirky world.

I would definitely recommend this to anyone thats looking for a laugh.

reviewText:
Yeah, I'm having the same problem describing this game as others seem to have had.  I guess it just is what it is? Anyway, had a BLAST playing, kinda sad it's a little short but it's not like it's not worth the price because it blody well IS!

For some reason the opening credits reminded me of Get Smart, The Avengers (Steed & Peel, not Rogers & Stark) and the 70's while the rest of the game is pure Hunter S Thompson as interpreted by Johnny Depp & Benicio Del Toro. I washed windows, I killed and cooked a mechanical pig on wheels, I broke my legs jumping off a diving board, I waxed a tarantula, I dug up a wooly mammoth in ice, I failed miserably at minigolf and virtual tennis and I killed pizza zombies. All while carrying a fly swatter. Or maybe not.

I'm not going to tell you that you MUST play this game, but I will say that if you do buy it and play it, you're almost certain to enjoy every moment of the surreality contained within.

reviewText: Jazzpunk is a single-player, first-person adventure game, focusing on exploration and comedy over puzzle-solving. Each mission has one central objective, but the player is free to explore the game world at their own pace, which is populated with a large number of interactive NPCs, each with their own action or gag. The player takes the role of Polyblank, a silent protagonist. The game begins when Polyblank is mailed to the espionage agency in a human-shaped suitcase. He is then given several missions by the head of the organization, all of which begin by ingesting a dose of prescription medicine. The missions assigned to Polyblank are almost always bizarre and nonsensical, relying heavily on free association and references to older movies and video games. Tasks include degaussing and smuggling pigeons, assassinating cowboys, cross-dressing, killing a pig with a ukulele, and photocopying Polyblank's bottom to fool a security scanner. The game was originally created as a prototype in 2007, running on a standalone engine. The project was then transferred to Torque3D before being transferred to the Unity game engine, on which the final build was created.

So, the most common negative side of this game I can see in the reviews is the length of this game. I completely disagree. You can play this game for way more than 2 hours. It's hilarious and there's plenty of hidden treats to find if you really dive into this game completely. There were moments where I was literally laughing out loud. Not many games have managed to do that.
The only downsides I experienced was the lack of details in some places. You've basically been told by the game to explore as much as possible but in some cases there's a lack of depth and there's this feeling that they could've put more work into it. That feeling was very rare though.
Liked Stanely Parable or just random witty humour? You'll love this.

9/10

reviewText: Jazzpunk isn’t for everyone, and players willing to invest in its sense of silliness and extraneous satire will undoubtedly find stretches they’ll need to endure while searching out the next slice of brilliance. Whether or not it’s worth it is going to wildly differ from person to person.  So I’ll end with a vague recommendation; give Jazzpunk a go if you’re in the mood to nerd it up for an evening, but don’t blame me if you expect a game that asks you to photocopy your ♥♥♥♥ to act as an I.D. picture to be high humour.\n\nFull Review -- http://www.honestgamers.com/12199/pc/jazzpunk/review.html

reviewText:
Take one part Get Smart, one part Warioware, a generous splash of Ren and Stimpy, liquify then shake well and what your left with is Jazzpunk. A wholly unique and incredibly fun game. It is, hands down, one of the best games I've played in ages. Considering how simple of a game it is that may seem like an exaggeration, but that's the truth.

The entirety of the gameplay is essentially walking around and clicking on just about anything you can see. However, inside the simple gameplay is a wealth of humor and absurdism so abundant that it bursts through the simplicity to smack you in the face, leaving you asking for more. This is a really short game, I mean extremely so, and I would have loved for it to be longer. But really, there's so much packed into what little length there is that I know if I play through it again I'll find more goodies, side quests, and easter eggs that I didn't see the first few times around.

I wholeheartedly recommend this game. I got this way below the asking price in a bundle, but it is more than worth the full fifteen dollars. If you can get it cheaper, then great, but consider buying it full price if you can't because it's a great game that everyone should try.

reviewText: Jazzpunk is really great. It's the kind of game the Zucker Brothers (Airplane, The Naked Gun) would make if they were around and playing games during the Nintendo 64 era. The humor is mostly really really silly, but there's so many gags thrown in there that eventually one will pop up that really makes you laugh. The whole game feels more like a fun toy than a game with a well defined structure. Most of the areas have lots and lots of optional things to play with or people to get dialogue from. There's almost nothing else out there like Jazzpunk, and I wish I could play it all over again without knowing the gags. I recommend it.

reviewText:
Worth: Big Discount                      Memorability: Distinct
Aesthetic: Fun                                Audio: Surreal

Pros: As someone who is enamoured with surrealism, this kept my attention through to the very end. It is fashioned like LSD: Dream Simulator for PSX. Levels are dream-like in consistency and style, while sound serves to bemuse and disorient.

Cons: Difficulty seesaws illogically. FOV is messed up; at best, you will constantly be butting into things. At worst, you will get motion sickness. Final level is not designed well, making it inordinantly-laggy. Rather short for it's undiscounted asking price.

Overall: It's not worth $15.00USD, but it's comedic eyecandy and worth a night of drunkplay with that distinguishable Adult Swim style.

Score:7/10

reviewText:
This is not a game you can validate in a review.

Which is what I'm trying to convince you to do.
Crap.

Okay. So...
Questionairre time!
Do you like humor?
Do you like games?
Do you like ANYTHING?

If you answered no to any of these questions, I'm sorry.
But you are not worthy of Jazzpunk.
Otherwise, buy it.
Trust me, I'm a doctor.
Just kidding, I'm a spy.
Just kidding, I'm a forest fire.

reviewText:
This game got me from a exact moment when I met The Evil Dead II and the Shining reference in one room with zombies and pizza! XD

I finished the game after 4 hours, but it was 4 hours of hysterical laugh I didn't have since Hot Shots! (1991)" watching it for a first time when I was a kid.

In short for buying the game: Are you interested in Mind'F'uck interactive movie full of 80-90's movie/computer/games references playing(acting) in main role of a spy agent? Then go for it.

For the rest of the recommendation I'll just shoot references I met:
- Wilhelm scream
- Frogger
- Evil Dead II
- The Shining
- Captain Crunch
- Tetris theme
- Warcraft

- James Bond
- QUAKE
- Star Wars

reviewText:
Yeah, I'm having the same problem describing this game as others seem to have had.  I guess it just is what it is? Anyway, had a BLAST playing, kinda sad it's a little short but it's not like it's not worth the price because it blody well IS!

For some reason the opening credits reminded me of Get Smart, The Avengers (Steed & Peel, not Rogers & Stark) and the 70's while the rest of the game is pure Hunter S Thompson as interpreted by Johnny Depp & Benicio Del Toro. I washed windows, I killed and cooked a mechanical pig on wheels, I broke my legs jumping off a diving board, I waxed a tarantula, I dug up a wooly mammoth in ice, I failed miserably at minigolf and virtual tennis and I killed pizza zombies. All while carrying a fly swatter. Or maybe not.

I'm not going to tell you that you MUST play this game, but I will say that if you do buy it and play it, you're almost certain to enjoy every moment of the surreality contained within.

reviewText:
If you can get this on sale, it's very much worth it. I bought it at 75% off and that seems like a fair price for the enjoyment I got out of it. I would not recommend buying it at full price.

Cons:

-When I played it in early 2015, achievements did not work whatsoever in Linux
-Limited replay value (might not be as much of a problem if achievements worked)

reviewText:
What to say about Jazzpunk? It's a blast in every way possible.
Ok, the world is limited and the graphics are basic. Who cares? The personality and originality of this game surpasses any other. Set during the Cold War, it's a mockery of conspiracy and the fear of new technology that abounded in that era.
You enter each level by taking pills, then you have to solve the puzzles using the craziest interactions possible to discover who the bad guy is. There is plenty to explore in each level that doesn't have to do with the main story.
By the way, this game predicted ebola.
Fun includes: Zapping pigeons, killing pizza, turning on the fire and ice alarms, playing WeddingQuake, putting as much makeup on as you want, catching a robotic pig, racing gravy dishes, killing someone in a pillowfight, and getting eaten by a crocodile  (or is it an alligator?)

reviewText: Very funny game. You're a secret agent in times of cold war and your task is to infiltrate various places and do typical agent stuff - steal plans, neutralize someone, general spying. Visual style is quite nice, story and humor are excellent. Main storyline is quite short ~ 2 hours but there is a huuuge amount of side quests, easter eggs and stuff to explore. If you're looking for something really funny and good, this is a game for you! The amount of jokes in this game is absolutely incredible. Laughs guaranteed!\n\nI am pretty sure I have not seen 3/4 of the things this game has to offer as I only did the main story and a few easter eggs. Achievements shouldn't be to hard to do, so if you're looking for an easy and pleasant game to 100%, go and play it! :)

reviewText:
If this game was a meal it would be one from one of those take-away places where the menu has a picture that makes it look like Heston Blumenthal works in the kitchen but what you get is a brown paper bag with a passable burger and some listless fries.

Let's try and concoct a genre tag for this one. Interactive pun simulator? Burroughs-em-up? It's a distracting and fairly enjoyable little thing, but this is ultimately a once only experience. I wouldn't recommend dropping more than £5 on this if you can avoid it given a loose £/hr enjoyment ratio you can get everywhere else.

I'm all for doing something a bit different within the concept of a 'game'. What Jazzpunk provides is an on-rails 'experience' telling a somewhat surreal story laced with puns and references to hard-boiled detective fiction and gaming staples and offering up a few puzzles to solve on the way.

Whilst never exactly actively bad it does suffer from being overly drawn out in places and the general pacing feels a little disjointed. The puzzles seem to actually get less difficult as the story progresses, perhaps this was a intentional 'thing' but if so the point of it was lost on me.
If you've played games long enough to anticipate some of the usual game design language (the items hidden in the bind corner, if the game points you left have a quick look to the right, pull the lever that appears to do nothing etc) then don't bother chasing after the intriguing possibilities in Jazzpunk. There a lot of hidings to nothing to waste your time on for no reward.

I really am trying to be positive about this game, I'm giving it a thumbs up because it's not actiively awful.
What there is is very nicely made, there's nothing technically wrong with it, but ultimately when reaching the end I was just left with a general feeling of Oh. Well that happened.
Next!"."

reviewText:
In my short time with this game I've infiltrated the Soviet Embassy, devoured countless pharmaceuticals, committed insurance fraud, played miniature golf, stolen a top secret cybernetic kidney, and boxed a sedan to the death. Jazzpunk is filled to the brim with personality, humor, and enough WTF moments to make even the most seasoned adventure gamer blush.

The setting alone is worth the price of admission; Imagine Mad Men meets Blade Runner written by the folks who brought you Airplane and directed by Tim Schafer. Sure, it may only clocks in at four hours; but it never ceases to be utterly engrossing as well as hilarious. I've not played something so memorable, so provocative, so weird as this in quite some time.

If you're a fan of spy movies, satire, adventure games, cyberpunk, copious amounts of alcohol, or simply want a fresh experience then JazzPunk is your most certainly for you.

reviewText:
Hilarious! Art! These two words are ones almost never in the same sentence together, which is why I separated them with exclamation points. Separated or not though, Jazzpunk is both of these things.
But to get to the point, (before I start talking about the weather or something, which i'm sure is nice where you live (if not, then I'm sure it's not nice (that is to say, I'm sure the weather is well weathered where you live (that really isn't what I was trying to say, but the 'weather is well weathered' pun is demonstrating the type of joke that can be found within Jazzpunk (You're welcome!))))) the real brilliance of Jazzpunk is how it frequently allows the player to transcend the main narrative in favour of allowing pointless exploration. The game itself is really more about the funny* hidden jokes than the silly storyline. So I only recommend this game if you have the patience to examine every little thing you come across. Or if you are an achievement hound. Because the achievements in this game are both numerous and drop-dead easy.

All in all, I had a great time with this title! 9/10!

*I take no responsibility for any un-funny jokes you come across. If you do come across an un-funny joke, don't message me with hate-mail telling me how much of a lying fool I am; instead take a step back** and re-evaluate your life.*** Look out the window! Watch the people outside swinging from tree to tree!**** Is it really worth the effort complaining to me!? The guy who will just delete your carefully worded hate message? And more importantly, maybe take a closer look and see if the joke you were complaining about is even really a joke! Not everything is you know. Unlike your life.*** #ohsnap

**Do NOT do this if you are standing on the edge of a cliff.

***I write this based on the assumtion that you actually have a life. My apologies if I have misjudged you.

****I write this based on the assumption that you live in an alternate universe where everyone is obsessed with George of the Jungle and favours vines and trees over cars and trains. My apoligies if I have misjudged you.

reviewText:
Oh boy, Jazzpunk.

There are not a lot of games out there which force me to laugh out loud while being home alone in front of my computer screen, but Jazzpunk certainly is one of them. I literally LOL’d quite a few times while playing this game.

This game is so silly I can’t even begin writing about it, so I’ll just paste the Steam store description:

“Jazzpunk is a comedy adventure set in an alternate reality Cold War World, plagued with corporate espionage, CyberCrime, and sentient martinis. Gameplay is inspired by spoof comedy films and cartoons of yesteryear, with a focus on weird gadgets, exotic locales, and open-world style exploration.“

You have to experience it yourself. It’s worth it.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t2i9DDw5q-o

Plus, it reminds me of games like Gravity Bone and Thirty Flights of Loving from Blendo Games.

reviewText:
If you locked a handful of game developers in a room with a plethora of drugs, some William Gibson and Ian Fleming novels and a PC with a copy of Gone Home you would get something that resembles Jazzpunk.

Lots of tasteful pop culture references, slatherings of satire and a handful of mini-games made this rather linear adventure very entertaining.

My main criticism is that it's a little on the short side... but any longer and its charm and novelty may have grown thin.

10/10 would Jazzpunk again.

reviewText:
More information here: http://www.brokencartridge.net/games/review-jazzpunk/ (features a video review!)

You will laugh, you will cry, but mostly you will be confused. Jazzpunk is an avant-garde comedy adventure inspired by spoof films and old slapstick cartoons. In this cyberpunk style world with an alternate reality Cold War theme, you are some type of spy or investigative agent. You are sent on missions finding cases of corporate espionage and “CyberCrime” in an open world.

Jazzpunk will leave you scratching your head as much as it will be making you laugh. Each level has a main mission you must accomplish, but that is just the surface of what the game is all about. Expecting the unexpected will do you no good as you will still be absolutely bewildered at what lies behind every corner. Find a pizza box next to an old bum in the street corner? Open it and find that it brings you to another pizza world where you must kill pizza zombies with your oversized pizza pan and cutter. Surprises like that are waiting for you behind nearly every intractable object.

A large amount of content in the game is not mandatory for completion, but that is what makes it so great.  You feel the impulse to cover every inch of each area to ensure that everything is experienced, because it is definitely worth exploring. Maybe you will steal the entry ticket to the hotel rooms, and in one you will find a bride and groom with their wedding cake that transports you into a wedding edition of Quake, or possibly have sex with a robot ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. The possibilities and expectations are endless and worth every moment.

One thing I quickly realized is that there is no sense of challenge throughout the entire game. Essentially there is no way to fail or do something wrong. While this insures that you will never have to do the same thing twice or the hear same joke multiple times, it also removed some depth to certain scenes. Comedy is the game’s forte, which is great in its own sense but ends up revoking any type of challenge the game could possibly offer. If that is good or bad depends on the player, but it is definitely something worth noting.

Even though I took my time trying to explore as much as possible, I still beat the game within 3 hours. That was slightly disappointing seeing how it is a 15 dollar title. Playing the game through multiple times is advised, because there will definitely be things that you missed. I would have liked to see a few more levels packed in there, though. I actually had an interest in the story and where it was going, but in retrospect is was a very short one. The game had some minor technical issues as well, such as crashing when trying to mess with the video settings in game. It wasn’t dual monitor friendly, either. I ended up having to use a control to properly play the game, which is still fine because it is perfectly playable with the standard Xbox controller, but let that be a warning to dual monitor users out there that you may have a few issues.

Jazzpunk is an excellent game with a grand sense of humor and a unique style of play. We’ve never seen anything like it, and I doubt we ever will again. It shows that sometimes all we need is something different slapped onto our face. Adult Swim’s streak of publishing interesting games continues.

reviewText:
Jazzpunk is a comedy in the burgeoning sub genre of first person games like Gone Home or Thirty Flights of Loving that seek to tell a linear story in a non-linear experience by shepherding the protagonist with incentives. This review is the hardest review I've ever attempted to write. Being a comedy, and a video game, many of the jokes are deadpan and are uniquely structured to the levels of the game. Because of that there were levels that hit the mark, such as Wedding Quake were hilarious. Often times though there were jokes in levels that matched that were nearly identical to each other in structure, cadence and delivery right after each other that were not only not funny but actively served to make subsequent new jokes in that level less funny.

This fault of the game seems to be a result of the non-linear structure. Due to it being a non-linear game there are many chances to miss things. Due to this they would reuse minigames and even types of jokes. That said reused jokes can be funny. There are multiple instances where you are sent through a zombie pizza hut minigame trifle, and each time it gave me goosebumps and it would cause uncontrollable laughter. Most of the jokes are not given as much car as the pizza hut gag or Wedding Quake and are mere stand-up routines. There are instances when multiple non-player characters in levels will give similar routines but not quite the same, and these jokes fall flat.

Jazzpunk in many ways is a stark realization that game developers growing up playing Nintendo 64 games are now making games of their own. It’s a weird artifact from an era that went in a different direction, when minigames dominated and there were a torrent of incentives deployed at the player character to get them to complete a non-linear environment in a linear way. In the end, what this boils down to is a unique refreshing experience that's comedy doesn't hack it the whole way through.

reviewText:
Jazzpunk is a difficult game to review, but I'll give it my best shot.

Wow would be a simple word to describe this game. If there is such a thing as a God, it is Jazzpunk.

Jazzpunk is a very much experimental game, infusing just about everything under the sun with puns. Alot of puns. Jazzpunk also incorporates just about any game you can think of into one neat little package. Pizza version of Nazi Zombies. Here. Quake game based around weddings. Here.

The story line, while short, is funny and compelling at the same time. The story focuses on espionage, set in a bright world that enfuses new technology with a background of bright, and colourful Art Deco motifs. There is a ton of exploring to do, easter eggs to find, and whole new games to play! If you follow the main story path, you're looking at 2, maybe 3 hours of gameplay. But combined with all the secrets, achivements and down right silly side-quests, you could easily extend your playtime to 4-5 hours or even more!

I expected a more Thirty Flights of Loving feel to Jazzpunk, but I was mistaken. Jazzpunk (it's just such a fun word to say) is it's own game, heck, it's own genre. It's much more in your face" than Thirty Flights of Loving
date: but that isn't always a bad thing. Jazzpunk is just a silly
hoursPlayed: but doesn't take it too far but actually making all these silly things funny. Granted

reviewText: I made a cowboy ♥♥♥♥ out his kidney, I killed people with a fly swatter, I made a turtle into a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle, I played golf with a pool cue, I watched bacteria have sexy time, I became a DJ, I got kissed by a hobo. This 90's set game is all about a spy called Polyblank completing missions that just want to make you laugh and smile. Extremely random. The amount of creativity is unbelieveable. I suggest you buy the game whenever you can. It may be short. But You don't want to stop playing over and over again. ~ Thank you creators of Jazzpunk for the entertaining hours. Looking forward to more games made by you in the future. 9.5/10

reviewText: Very short game for the price. That said, you can tell some love went into this game and it reflects the kind of humor you'd expect for something connected to Adult Swim very well. I personally think it's wonderful, creative and unique in it's style, and if this were a five star system, I'd say four out of five. Hell, I made an avatar out of it. I just really wish there was more to play. However, given that there seem to be a lot of little jokes hidden through the game (ICQ, anyone?), I'm wondering what I missed, which begs at least one replay, so there is that to consider.\n\nAll in all, solid fun without a doubt, but at $15, I was expecting more than 3 hours of story-driven play. Wait for a sale, but definitely pick it up eventually.

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game in a way I wasn't expecting.

It has the right amount of humour and always in places you never expect to find it. You never know what you're going to come up against next, but you're guaranteed to laugh. Of course you could probably run straight through the game, do the tasks and finish it, but then you'd miss everything else going on. It's a game where you feel rewarded by looking at every little detail because so much of it has extra things to offer. It's not all in your face either, constantly forcing you to be in a typical funny situation. In fact a lot of the comedy in the game is quite subtle and you have to steer from the path in order to find it, but it makes you appreciate it as you play through. The attention to comedic detail is quite marvelous.

The gameplay is nice and simple. You walk around, interact with objects in often fun and ingenious ways to complete puzzles and make your way through the story. The graphics are very cartoony but still maintains a great atmosphere with all the music and extra sounds going on. It suits the tone of the game perfectly.

It's something nice, different and random. Nothing like I have played before and definitely a great experience. Would recommend.

reviewText:
Watching 10 minutes of Jazzpunk will let you know whether it's for you or not. Its brand of humour is hyper-specific, trading on James Bond, conspiracy theories, William Gibson and a dash of Blendo Games' work. If that type of humour appeals to you then stop reading, buy Jazzpunk, play Jazzpunk.
Jazzpunk may be the funniest game I've ever played. Humour is brutally difficult in games because the player is in control of the timing. Jazzpunk nails it, almost effortlessly. It's a game that rewards you poking at everything, and everything you poke is guaranteed to have a joke attached. The concentration of lunacy is consistently dense. The number of jokes per square metre in this game is ridiculous. There's so much to find and so much to discover. A few jokes fall flat but the majority of them work and work well.
Jazzpunk is essentially an adventure game. Often you'll be asked to collect certain items to combine with other items to progress. It sounds dull but virtually every puzzle is a clever joke or a stupid premise. Jazzpunk's objectives embrace the non-sequiter and the punchline and weave them into everything you do.
Remember bubsy3d.com? Recall the end scene? Remember the Applebees? Jazzpunk's puzzles and easter eggs rival that moment in their sheer audacity every two minutes.
It took some incredibly intelligent people to make a game that's so smart about being dumb. Even if it seems like it's not for you, you should play this game. It's a delight.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This takes me back to my childhood, playing adventure games, Point and clicks, Grim Fandango, Indiana Jones, Lucas Arts. I loved it from start to finish, I`ve just played through it and I`m considering playing it again just to get all the achievments. I can`t remember the last time I felt that way after playing a game, but its been a while.

The characters and the universe is charming, the controls are easy and the story is fun. The whole cold war spy thing was a great setting and the music suits that theme brilliantly. Wacky, intelligent, and entertaining.

I think I recognised one of the bar patrons ;) kudos Necrophone. Only minus I can seem to find is that the game was a bit short, but I do prefer a short quality game over a long game where you can see the story dabbing off and becoming dull.

reviewText:
Full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/jazzpunk-game-review/

Well, this was one of the more interesting titles I’ve played of late. Certainly one of the most humorous games I’ve played in my life, that’s for sure. There’s just so many things right about Jazzpunk.

Jazzpunk is a first-person comedy-adventure game set during the cold war, in an alternate reality. The game places large emphasis on open-world exploration, which can be seen immediately in the first level. I spent the majority of my time in the game exploring, rather than actually playing through the main story, although I did manage to beat the entire game in about two hours. The game’s length being my major complaint. For such a great game, I’d like more than just two hours.

Unique. If I had to use one word to describe Jazzpunk, that’d be it. The game is full of references, side quests, and plenty of areas to explore in the various chapters. I even helped clean a guy’s massive ear out when he was unable to hear. Just one of the silly things that can be accomplished within the several chapters. Oh, and the dialogue. Fantastic. Simply fantastic. A lot of the characters in-game spoke like robots and it seemed like there were new accents everywhere I went.

Jazzpunk is heavy on its comedic appeal. There are several instances in the game that serve no purpose other than to make you laugh. I ran into a shop at one point whose door simply said “closed for no reason”. There’s plenty of new things to find when exploring the worlds of each chapter, and, like I said, that’s where I had spent most of my playtime, looking around. It’s overwhelming at times, the amount of stuff that you can find whilst exploring.

The game uses an interesting art style. I want to say its cel-shaded, but I don’t know if that’d be correct. For the most part, it does look like its cel-shaded, which is always a art style. Nothing to complain about in terms of the game’s graphics.

If you’re going to pick up Jazzpunk, don’t expect much in terms of length if you just play through the game’s story. Instead, spend some time exploring about. You’ll find yourself laughing at the numerous scenes scattered throughout the game.

reviewText:
Ok, i have had polarizing opinions on this game, but here goes.

When you first start the game, you're greeted by attempting to infiltrate the Soviet Consulate. And then, as you're about to go up, you're greeted by a guy who tells you to go find a mailbox with chalk on the side, which you can ignore or follow. (There's no prompt to do so.) On my first playthrough i ignored, and i was greeted by a boring fetch mission with a glitchy dial phone, which then lead to a pretty boring game, purely because i put no time into it. It was short and un-appetizing, and the humor almost felt juvenile. But, on the second playthrough, i decided to follow the things the NPCs told me and i had a ♥♥♥♥ing blast. The side missions easily added 3 times the game's face value, and all the side missions and easter eggs felt actually funny. So, that's it.

8/10, please follow the side missions for a much superior experience.

Also, there is a parody of Quake called Wedding Qake built in, it's fantastic and addicting. Wedding Qake: 8/10, lack of options.

reviewText:
Ok, i have had polarizing opinions on this game, but here goes.

When you first start the game, you're greeted by attempting to infiltrate the Soviet Consulate. And then, as you're about to go up, you're greeted by a guy who tells you to go find a mailbox with chalk on the side, which you can ignore or follow. (There's no prompt to do so.) On my first playthrough i ignored, and i was greeted by a boring fetch mission with a glitchy dial phone, which then lead to a pretty boring game, purely because i put no time into it. It was short and un-appetizing, and the humor almost felt juvenile. But, on the second playthrough, i decided to follow the things the NPCs told me and i had a ♥♥♥♥ing blast. The side missions easily added 3 times the game's face value, and all the side missions and easter eggs felt actually funny. So, that's it.

8/10, please follow the side missions for a much superior experience.

Also, there is a parody of Quake called Wedding Qake built in, it's fantastic and addicting. Wedding Qake: 8/10, lack of options.

reviewText: Jazzpunk is another game that, like Zeno Clash, tries to be held up entirely by weirdness.  It fails just as spectacularly.  Behind the extreme weirdness, there is nothing interesting nor compelling just a bland game full of random occurences and random references.  I would liken it to the recent teenage buzzword random":  It feels like a desperate cry for attention by being different when in reality it's rather predictable and not the least bit interesting.\n\nGameplay consists of walking around and interacting with various objects and completing very short side missions while you accomplish your main objective for each level.  There are only a couple missions and they go by quickly.  The game tries really hard to be funny but there's not much humor to be found when nothing makes any sense
date: barring a couple lines from side characters.\n\nFrom a technical standpoint
recommended: the game is a bit odd.  It has very simple graphics and should run on a toaster due to that but for some reason is limited to 60 fps.  Keyboard movement keys are not set by default so you have to do it yourself and the mouse control is very sluggish and stuttery.  The game also stutters occasionally.  All of these things are extremely strange for a game running on the Unity engine but it doesn't get in the way too much.\n\nSo to summarize Jazzpunk is a very weird game held up entirely by weird random references and humor
hoursPlayed: neither of which work.  How this game has gotten over 90% positive reviews completely baffles me."
voteText: November 6, 2014

reviewText:
Ok so the game isn't anything, there's no gameplay worthy of note here -- it's an adventure game with no brain required. Not a good start, but alright. So it's an art game then. Therefore it has to be pretty, deep, or funny enough to make up for what it's already missing.

Well it isn't pretty. There can be beauty in simplicity, but this isn't that.

It isn't deep. There's no atmosphere, I'm not even convinced the game has a plot.

And, well, it seems like the game really thinks its funny but it just isn't. I can appreciate some cheap humor but that's all the game has. I chuckled at some opening gags but the charm quickly wore thin. There's no effort put into developing jokes, nor do any gags require even the slightest bit of brain activity. There's no characterization, no charm.

It's like sitting through a comedy show where the humor never gets beyond, a man steps into a bar -- ouch.""

reviewText: Blah I really wanted to like this game. Watching the trailer, the surreal comedy and art style really appealed to me, reminded me of what I loved so much about Tom Robbins' books (Skinny legs especially). Then I started reading reviews, which harped on juvenile jokes, easy puns and casual racism and basically wrote it off my list. For whatever reason, I felt compelled to pick it up on sale and finally got around to playing it recently.\n\nSometimes, a spade is just a spade. I know it's bad, but I just couldn't make it more than 30 minutes into this game... everything just reinforced all of the negative press it received. If you respect your time and intelligence, I just wouldn't bother with this one.

reviewText: You know looking back on it, this is one of the worst games I've ever played. When I first went through it, I was excited. It was weird and fairly stylish. Why is that in this game, it's not Warcraft! Hahahaha! What a great joke. It was also incredibly short, and had practically no real story. Utterly pretentious in every way imaginable.

reviewText:
Easter Egg Hunting: The Game

If you like running around looking at every single nook and cranny in a vibrant 1960's spy movie, here's your game.
-The humor is okay, not worth 15 bucks
-A lot of people comment on how short it is and I wish I could verify but after 15mins into the game I get physically nauseous. Sooo yeah...
Googled the nausea problem and I'm not the only person with this issue. Something about input lag and mouse filtering?
Tried some of the 'solutions' but none worked for me.
Buyer beware!

reviewText:
What a game this was.

First let me say that I have been playing a few comedy games as of late, so I potentially could be burned out on them as a genre.

I hate this game, this game from start to finish was in a word horrible. In a few words a horribly optimized, exceedingly gimmicky, and just plain boring game.

I'm not going to concern you with the plot. If you're interested in this game you know enough about the plot to get you started.  It uses the LOL so random ROFL gimmick to get a rise out of you, and then just stares at you when you don't laugh. Seeming to ask you What about the gun that turns pedestrians into pigeons don't you find funny?" And that's the thing
date: at first it sounds very funny
recommended: but after the tenth similar joke it gets to be really old and very grating. And then it drags it out for four more levels
hoursPlayed: begging you to laugh while you just sit silently staring at your screen.\n\nHonestly if you really need to play a comedy game

reviewText:
Quirky and fun, albeit short, game that's good if your looking for an hour or two to kill with some laughs. There's tons of little side things to explore and the art is unique and interesting, and most of the time your exploration is rewarded by the well-written comedy strewn about the game. Not a lot of games entice me to poke around every corner and click on everything like this one did. If this is your kind of humor, you'll probably love it. If not, well then you'll probably hate it.

Dunno if it's worth 15 dollars (the only reason I can think of why the price is so high is because the developers had to pay for A) Drugs that assisted with the creation of this game, or B) the Adult Swim logo.) but if you've got the extra cash and are prepared to throw it at your screen for a brief hour or two of complete and total confusion, then by all means try it out!

tl;dr This game broke my brain, rawr stars out of blarg.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2dU_3GWWZH4
Jazzpunk presents itself as a parody of spy movies, but quickly wears out its welcome with never ending references and sight gags, most completely unrelated to the task at hand, leaving you with a thin vein of a plot to serve as a vehicle from one joke to the next.

That’s not to say all the humour is bad, but a lot is random for the sake of being random. There's no narrative hooks for many of the jokes, they just exist for the sole purpose of delivering a punchline; experience it and move on. Funnily enough, the better jokes are ones that are actually tied into the game plot, making the others feel tacked on and unnecessary filler.

There reigns the problem with the game; if you don't make an active effort to seek these jokes out, you'll miss most the content of the game (possibly without even meaning to) and probably finish the game within an hour. Even looking for them I finished at just shy of three hours, with the ending just kind of happening rather than being built up to. £9.99 for a game that feels like it was a student's spare time project seems rather hefty to me. At that price point, I'd rather just go watch a terrible blockbuster comedy, I'd probably enjoy it just as much.

The game gets split up into levels, which are small but distinct zones. Actually, scrap small, most are tiny. They look nice enough, but they're mainly just straight lines with a few offshoots if you want to go indulge in the humour, and there is no other reason to go explore. There's not much else to say about the game because, well, there's not much else to the game. There's a bunch of mini-games, though Wedding Qake repeats, which was a ha ha

This is the game equivalent of going to a forum for the sole purpose of looking at a random assortment of animated gifs; just a series of out-of-context punchlines.

reviewText:
I'm a fan of comedy: on a stage, in film, on TV, in games, etc.  I also like many kinds of humor, but the jokes in this game could have only been of interest to a 10 year old version of myself.  Luckily I got this on sale, but even then, 2 hours of cringe-inducing attempts at humor really make this a poopy-at-best" experience.

It's enough there is practically no content.  Or that the sounds and voice acting are terrible (made worse if you play with headphones).  Or that the only high points are the swing wing and the mini games.

If you want a few chuckles but mostly want to groan
date: get this game.\n\nIf you want an actual game with actual funny moments: wait for if No One Lives Forever comes to Steam/GOG."

It wears thin fast. Oh good, it's over.

reviewText:
Weird, wacky and wonderful. I can't think of a better way to waste my afternoon with my pants on.

This is a fine addition to Adult Swim's stable of games. The opening sequence is inspired and is a demonstration of what can be done with minimalist graphics. The game play is straight foward and somewhat linear. I will play through again to pick up those little bits here and there I missed the first time. The humour is spot on and you'll probably find yourself laughing out loud at some of the silliness.

My only complaint is the abruptness with which the game ends. Hopefully there will be DLC to expand the missions and fun.

reviewText: When I bought Jazzpunk I did not know what this game was about. After playing the game to completion I still don't. This is a game that even once it hints things are going to start to make sense, throws a curve ball of absurdity right at your face. The best way to describe this would be taking Bubsy 3D or Frog Fractions and mixing it with Thirty Flights of Loving or Gravity Bone. I enjoyed every minute of it, and I desperately want to jump back in and try to find the things I missed. Highly recommended if you are a fan of absurdist comedy and referencial humor.

reviewText:
90’s cartoons + film noir + 90’s video game references.
So there I was browsing the steam store at the beginning of the summer sale, hundreds of games on sale, with crazy deals, like 60-80% off some great games, from great game makers. Plenty of tried and true games for me to buy, from franchises that probably wouldn’t disappoint, but I was looking for something new, something interesting, something I hadn’t played before, and by golley did I find it. So just what is jazzpunk, you say? Well the short answer would be that it’s a walking sim, but the long answer would be a trippy, windy road, full of some of the most distinct hummer I’ve ever seen in a game.

The game opens up by dumping you off of a luggage conveyer belt, into a sweeping montage of abstract imagery, full of Japanese symbols, air planes, and radio waves. It looks like something that could have been taken from the intro of an old western movie, if the motif were jazz, and not the Wild West. When it’s over, you get tossed in something that looks like a 50’ds-60’ds office space, crossed with a train station, and yes you can immediately start talking to boxes that are lying around.

A couple of minutes later and boom you’re in the full swing of the games plot, working as a secret agent  for the “Director”, and his “Secretary”. Right when you sit down on the whoopee cushion, to talk to your new boss, little white cartoonish lines come out of his eyes directing you towards you’re first mission objective, which is to raid some kind of Russian compound. Rite from the get go, you can get a good idea of what this games all about. Then you take you’re happy pills and go off into crazy land. This kind cartoonish hummer is bursting forth from almost every inch of the game. And that’s defiantly its strongest point, unlike most other walking sims this game won’t ever leave you board, whether you’re talking to insane hobos, hipster pies, that where sunglasses, and smok cigarettes, or talking to sexy female robots, there is always some business to poke your nose into. The game is also full of crazy side quests that you can get from talking to said persons such as; destroying clay pots in a fly shop, helping a frog cross the freeway to get his startreck data visor, catching huge spiders in a glass jar, in some Japanese themed restaurant, just to throw them on the cook’s face, who hates spiders.

This game is full of WTF moments that will have you smiling, and laughing out loud, as it pulls out gage after gage, most of which can be traced back to classic Ren and Stimpy cartoon's, and video game hummer. I even remember thinking halfway through the game “Ok, when are they going to start playing The Thieving Magpie theme?” and sure enough, there it was in the final level. But it’s really more than a one trick pony as far as the type of gages the game pulls off. Some of them are dialog based, some teleport you into areas where you are fighting cars, street fighter style in first person, and others are things like pulling an ice alarm, that’s located right next the proper fire alarm. Ice alarm, “for what reason”, one might ask one’s self? Why, for the same reason the hallway right next to it has a caution greased up floor" sign on it. “Well that doesn’t make any sense.” you might say

reviewText: When I bought Jazzpunk I did not know what this game was about. After playing the game to completion I still don't. This is a game that even once it hints things are going to start to make sense, throws a curve ball of absurdity right at your face. The best way to describe this would be taking Bubsy 3D or Frog Fractions and mixing it with Thirty Flights of Loving or Gravity Bone. I enjoyed every minute of it, and I desperately want to jump back in and try to find the things I missed. Highly recommended if you are a fan of absurdist comedy and referencial humor.

reviewText: A sturdy 10/10\nAlthough it may not be your typical game, this is precisely why Jazzpunk is so great. It's only downside is the fact that it is such a short game. Whacky humor and a lot of wtf moments is what sums this game up. Plenty of sidequests and achievements to get are unfortunately not enough to grant this game significant replay value. However, it is still definitely worth getting so you can make your friends come round to play and watch them as they sit in front of the screen baffled and bemused.\nA worthy buy.

reviewText:
Input settings are easy to break (assign mouse0 to anything and you won't be able to navigate the menu anymore!); when the game tells you to press A to sit down nothing happens, I had to go back to the settings to assign A to some action (that was NOT assigned with the default settings); and then during the game when you move the mouse very often the camera will rotate a lot in one frame which makes the game annoying to play.
Another nuisance, the voices are very hard to understand and not subtitled.

If there wasn't those problems the game might be fun, I don't know... It's unplayable in this state.

Edit: 7 months and not a single update later, I tried again and played a bit even though the mouse controls are still terrible. The game has annoying music and not volume settings, most jokes aren’t funny at all, boring quests"
date: and on top of it I haven’t been able to progress on the first task that you’re given."

reviewText: Jazzpunk is one of the many ridiculous titles published by Adult Swim in the last couple years, thankfully it is the good kind of ridiculous. It is just silly and smart enough to make it worth recommending. On the surface the plot of Jazzpunk seems insignificant but there is quite a bit that is left implied that encourages thought. I finished the game in about two hours, however that isn't exactly a problem: the game relies on its humor and I could see it getting stale if the game were a few more hours long. If I had trouble with anything during my time with Jazzpunk, it was the soundtrack. It is a fantastic soundtrack and works excellently with the game, however when exploring the levels sometimes the looped music would become grating. It doesn't offer much in replayability either but there is a lot of variety to the game, offering some neat minigames and secrets. If you are interested in some memorable comedy, Jazzpunk has you covered.\n\nI paid ~$0.33 for Jazzpunk as part of the Humble Weekly Bundle: Extra Life 2015 bundle.

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kTVdDY12fTc&list=PLBqXrq67D6opHuCAeV8nc8nAY2h0Gp4wg&index=1

Jazzpunk for me is like the drug you're looking for after coming home from work. It relaxes you, makes your jaw hurt from so much laughing at hilarious, sometimes idiot moments.

There's a lot of easter eggs, references to gaming, movies, politics, anything you can imagine. There should definitely be more seasons/episodes for Jazzpunk.

Recommended if you don't mind being placed in awkward situations.

reviewText:
Jazzpunk is a game that you won't know if you like it unless you experience it for yourself. As much as I enjoy these walking simulator games like The Vanishing of Ethan Carter and The Stanley Parable, Jazzpunk does not meet the quality you expect from these games by its narrative, immersion nor in its writing (especially its humor).

Warning: Epilepsy Gamers, Beware.
I wouldn't recommend this game as the intro screen and various moments in the game have tons of flashing lights.

Chalk Full of Gags, Little Else
Comedy is not something I'm going to critique the game for. It's too subjective, but I think I know who it's audience. This game comes across as another Youtube Bait game (Goat Simulator, etc.). The humor only seems to work off of LOL RANDOM NONSENSE
recommended: which makes the game itself feel shallow to play alone.\n\nThe game is chalk full of random mini-games
voteText: and tons of open environments with various gags to be found. If you explore everything and exhaust all the dialogue
helpfulPercent: you'll probably get five decent hours of a playthrough.\n\nBut with so many unnecessary nonsense gags
votesHelpful: you might grow tired from the game's charm after the first area. And don't expect getting a narrative worth those five hours (at best).\n\nIf You Still Want It
votesTotal:
Buy It On A Sale
There's nothing for me to analyze in its mechanics nor anything story-wise to keep me interested in reviewing Jazzpunk.

I liked the aesthetic
votesFunny: the soundtrack and the spy-hero gags/moments of the game. I wanted more of the riddiculous espionage humor
commentsCount:
but that gets burried amongst the LOL moments that I quickly grew bored of.

Some people may enjoy the more obscure references and the novelty of Jazzpunk.

I sure don't see the appeal of a game of easter eggs. What's the surprise if you know that is the gag?"
column16: November 7, 2015

reviewText: Let me tell you something about Jazzpunk, it is too often the problem with adventure games that the logic behind the puzzles is completely random nonsense, forcing you to hunt and peck everything against everything to succeed. Not so here! The nonsense behind the puzzles are completely consistent, and the designers did quite a good job of putting you into the headspace to solve their particular brand of Illogical challenges. Combine that with Some clever humor and terrific visuals and you have the makings of a masterpiece. My only fears for this game is that it will either sell Poorly preventing Stuff like it from being made in the future, or have negative reviews From casual gamers who just aren't quite ready for this outstanding experience.

reviewText:
Jazzpunk feels like a labour of love, a finely crafted adventure game crammed to the rim with zany, madcap humour; pop-culture references to please even the most devout hipsters; and wonderful little easter eggs. You can really tell the developers had a lot of fun making this game, but not as much as you will playing through it.

The only concern you should have with this title is its steep price, especially as you can finish the game in two hours, but this is definitely a must purchase when it goes on sale.

Remember; it's a fun thing, it's a Swing Wing!
voteText: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I found this game to be incredibly boring.  It tried way too hard to be funny but the lack of quality and variety in the art and voice acting just didn't do it for me.

Tone down the polygon count and some textures and this is something you could find on N64, yet the performance was still abysmal.  It seems as though there's a memory leak or something because sometimes performance gets progressively worse after certain events.  A 6-core CPU with a R9 290 should be able to handle this game.

I have often found myself struggling to point polyblank in a specific direction (when using a mouse+keyboard) where my view would sometimes change by 30 degrees when the mouse pointer may have only moved by 1 pixel.  Incredibly annoying.  I often found myself walking backwards towards a doorway since it was the only way I could control the direction I was moving in.

The music in the game was crap, most songs" only lasted maybe 20 seconds at most
date: and they were all on loop.  They also sounded like they had a 64Kbps compression.  On top of that
recommended:
the volume of many sound effects are way too loud.

You can't lose at the game and it gives absolutely no incentive to try anything.  I could complete an achievement and the game never acknowledges it.  The game is hardly a good time waster.

I have played free games made by amateurs that were more fun and higher quality than this.  Even without the technical issues
hoursPlayed: this would be the worst game I own on Steam by far."

reviewText:
Where do I begin...

Set during what I suppose is the Cold War, in what I THOUGHT was Japan, this is one trippy journey into a sweet ♥♥♥ world. I've always had a thing for the Eisenhower/JFK era: late 50s early 60s. I also had the pleasure to live in Japan, but my Pops, he had the pleasure to live in Japan during the Cold War. I play games not to get away, but to explore worlds I could never go in real life. This is the closest to 1960s Japan I'll probably ever get.

Jazzpunk is a first person exploration game. There's no real firm location except for one chapter.  The story is not very cut and dry. You play the role of a freelance Spy" operative. It's never really stated who you ultimately work for
date: but know The Director is your boss. Really
recommended: the story is not it's strength. It's more of a visual adventure into someone's trippy mind. You interact with the world and watch the results. Gags
hoursPlayed: and jokes galore. Oh the gags! It's hard to categorize the game
voteText: the fun is in your curiosity. Walk around each location
helpfulPercent: and EXPLORE. It's a visual piece of art in my opinion
votesHelpful: and the art design is superb. A "retro-futuristic" (think The Jetsons) Japanese aesthetic all thrown into a blender and somehow not coming out as sloppy as you would think. The music has it's strength. It works VERY well with the world. I can't even categorize the music...Latin

reviewText: The game was fun and entertaining to an extent as I found that most of the comedy was just alot of references to things that were only prominent in the 1990's.  References to things from years ago can be funny but when the majority of the comedy is only references then things that are prominent today will be more funny and less reaching.  as a game goes it is simplistic with an uninspired story and only 2 and a half hours of gameplay.  There are some really funny moments but the lasting power of those moments goes away quickly as you are constantly assaulted with these moments and references as the game is trying to scream at you look Im funny".  The way to get the most of your entertainment out of this game is to do everything before you actually complete your main objective which is a plus for the game to have some open exploration.\n\nMy final thoughts are simply that this game is pretty fun but has no challenge or real level of "game" to it; as it is trying to make you laugh with it's hit and miss comedy.  the overalll value however is what makes me have to say I would not recomend it because this is a 2 and a half hour game with little to no replayability what so ever.  Much like with a joke or comedy sketch you can only see it so many times before the punch is gone and you laugh more so out of politness than being actually entertained
date: and this game at $12 for 2 hours of content really makes me want alot more either game length or replayability."

reviewText: First of all, I think this is a good game". Why do I not recomend it? The biggest problem is the FOV. It is way too small. Please search Jazzpunk motion sickness. This game will cause most people to experience nausia or just feel terrible. I want to love this interactive gallery
date: but I simply can't sit down and enjoy it without feeling sick. Hopefully the developers will make a patch eventually to make it playable but that does not really look like it will be happening any time soon.\n\nThe writing is entertain and it is fun to explore except for the sick feeling."
